body.p:
Falmouth, Pendleton County Ky. July 22nd 1864
His Excellency
Tho E Bramlett Govr of Ky
Sir

At the last term of the Pendleton Circuit Court at the instance of Mr Carpenter, Comlths Attorney -- for this judicial Circuit I addressed a letter to you, informing you that Harrison Barns, against whom the Grand Jury of the County had found an Indictment for murder was running at large & suggested the propriety of offering a reward for his arrest -- Under that indictment and your Excellency' offer of reward for his apprehention he was arrested by Mr Pribble (I think it was) and lodged for trial in our Jail, where he remained securely (as was hoped) until the 25 June last when he, together with a runaway slave was by violence and force, set at liberty as detailed by the inclosed affidavit of the Jailor

If our own soldiers who come among us for the purpose of protection and the enforcement of the laws, are permitted to become the aggressors and violators of the
laws, and the lawless to be turned out from our Jails, and the lives and property of our citizen are to be preyed upon, and put in jeopardy by the military forces both from the North and the South; and this without remedy -- we have surely fallen upon evil times -- and not only the times, but the most valorous and patriotic loyal, are not without well founded apprehensions, that military powers and forces are ^to^ subordinate all civil rights, and ^ultimately to^ invite a state of affairs, which in days past, gave to her soil, the name of 'The blody ground' and which, God in his mercies, I pray, may avert --

Reward
$200
Pendleton Co
Harrison Barnes
Offered
12th Aug/64
